Bits of polystyrene packaging clung to the glossy furniture, the wiring was still being installed for the computers that had yet to be delivered, and the air was thick with the smell of fresh paint and newly laid carpet. People rushed to and fro, occasionally tripping over the boxes of unpacked paperwork scattered about.

It was chaos. Nobody knew who was who, what was where. Even though it had been two months since Open Day and creation of MI7, the new counter-intelligence and security agency intended to cope with the emerging extra-dimensional threats, it still felt as though they were racing to keep up with the situation that was spiraling out of control.

David Traynor sat at his desk, trying to massage away the dull pain in his right leg, which was unrelenting today. After a short while, he slid open his desk drawer, pulled out the bottle of gin that sat besides his badge and gun, and took a long series of shallow gulps. David would be the first to admit he wasn't cut out for this job. He was unfit, couldn't shoot for shit, and had been promoted by his superiors because the media had taken his actions on Open Day and made him a hero. He wasn't a hero, he was simply one of the few officers who had kept their head together while everybody else was losing theirs.

It had been the night shift when it happened. The phone lines had suddenly been swamped with thousands of calls all at the same time - countless reports of people going missing in their beds, wild animals in city centers, traffic accidents, mass panic. David had quickly pieced together a functional comprehension of what was happening - people were falling through holes in the air and becoming lost in the worlds that lay on the other side, meanwhile the open portals were allowing creatures to venture back here. It was like the Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe, except the lions were much less friendly and mauling people.

Armed with this rudimentary understanding, he had ventured into the nearest portal to find himself in a silent, dark forest. A old woman lay not far away on a twisted ankle, and he had returned with her thrown over his shoulder. The oil that powered the war machines ran dry, as did the coal used to smelt metal, and the uranium for the nuclear bombs that had decimated the planet. Slowly, the endless war wound down, returning to the age of infantry of old, where combatants fought each other with tooth and claw.

Though they may appear so at first, the beast men are not savages or barbarians. Their culture and technological understanding is great, they simply lack the resources to implement it for anything non-essential, such that their societies are a curious mix of the old and the new.

The war still wages. The stalemate is absolute, the battle lines dug deep and unchanging in generations. But perhaps the arrival of a new breed of humans and the opening of a portal to a world still (relatively) rich in mineral wealth can tip the balance in favour of your race.

Races
The indigenous humans of Earth primal are stunted and docile, with the intellect of animals. They live in the wild and are kept in captivity by the felinids.

A fully grown felinid stands anywhere from 7 to 11 feet tall, and resembles an upright walking big cat, like a tiger or leapard. Their females are ferocious warriors and hunters, while their males tend to be more subdued, living lives of leisure and partnered with multiple females.

The canids are evolved canines of roughly human height. Though not as physically imposing as the cats, they fight as highly effective packs following an alpha leader.

Reptilia are the most technologically advanced race, but are currently suffering a population crisis having been pushed from their historical breeding grounds. They are capable of changing gender according to the needs of the population.

You are a...
142.title: Earth Primal

choices: Go for the rare, red-crested female
1421.content:
One of the outlying thumpers has stopped functioning. The thumper line marks the extent of your tribe's territory - the large, rudimentary pylons constantly thumping the ground with a rock weight. The thumpers disturb the ground and make a tremendous noise, collapsing the tunnels and deafening the long ears of any rabbit that tries to burrow under. If they get inside, they'll run rampant, gorging themselves on the harvests and breeding like wildfire.

The thumpers form a roughly circular perimeter two hundred miles in length - there is some overlap, so that if one goes down, the neighbouring thumpers will hold the line until the broken one is up-and-running again. Even still, it should be fixed swiftly.

The leather strap of the rifle slung over you shoulder sits uncomfortably between your six breasts as you set out cross country, your long legs swiftly eating up the miles as you stride to your destination, a blot of bright orange and black fur moving across the green wilderness, a part of the world that in other realities would rest inside a place called India. It is nearing the end of the dry season, is hot and and humid, and you're naked apart from the satchel around your hips that contains your tools (and your fur of course).

Soon the top of the thumper comes into view over the forest canopy. It is a wide column of stone sticking twenty metres into the sky. The inside is hollow, containing a lead weight on a rope that is constantly winched up to the top of the column, whereupon the mechanism releases and sends the weight slamming into the earth, to repeat over again. It isn't a complicated machine, it was constructed to last. If they go down, it's usually sabotage.

The thumper stands silent and unmoving. As you near it, you unsling the rifle and proceed cautiously, your limbs moving with a silent, smooth grace despite their size. The rifle is a reassuring weight, it has been in your family for generations and is your most prized possession. Sliding through the foliage, the clearing that surrounds the thumper opens out before you.

An amused, relieved trill escapes your throat. It's no precursor to a canid attack, like you had feared. A number of human animals are clustered around the base of the thumper. They gape up at the structure in pure, dumb awe.

You like humans, though you've neither the time nor the patience to house and train one yourself, not with work as it is. You like their slow, docile natures, and the silly way they waddle about on their stumpy little legs. Your sister breeds them. She's constantly trying to fob you off with the runts of the litters, but you're happy enough just to play with them.

Sneaking forward so as not to alarm the creatures, you see that these are not wild nor feral animals, they've evidently escaped from their owner's home. For starters, they're far too clean to be wild. Plus they're wrapped up in fabric. You hate people who dress up their pets.

Your ears swivel forward, picking up their low, hooting cries. They almost sound like they're talking to one another.

"Tell me again how this is a natural rock formation," the large male says.

The female hoots back angrily, "If you're looking for an apology,-"

"And the things that looked like roads, those were just dried up river beds, yeah?"

"You've made your point. By all means, shut up now."

"And those weird radio noises that sounded like transmissions, those were just electromagnetic distortions in the atmosphere caused by solar flares. I mean, clearly you know best with your fancy degrees an' all. I'm just the dumb-as-bricks security guy." The male hoists a stick onto its shoulder, casting a furtive glance around the clearing. You duck down into the undergrowth. "That's it, we're done here. Get your equipment together and stop fucking poking it. We're leaving."

"We are not leaving!" the female mews shrilly. "Look at this thing! Mark, tell him."

A much scrawnier, paler human creature crouched down by the winching mechanism gives a shrug.

"I am looking at it, Professor. Clear evidence of habitation, meaning that under the quarantine act of 2014 we are required by law to evacuate immediately back to the portal and await a proper, armed investigative team from the government."

"Oh, fuck the government," the female in the long white garment screeches back heatedly. "This could be the find of my career."

"This planet could be dangerous."

"Don't be such an idiot. This thing is made of stone and lashed together with vines. Whoever built this was probably even stupider than you, and clearly hasn't even made it out of the stone age. We're perfectly safe."

Lifting the rifle sights to your eye, you gasp as the x10 magnification zooms in on the animals, as they continue to yabber incomprehensibly. Pedigrees! The female has a short mane of red hair and the two males, while less enticing, still display the pale skin seen only on the expensive, imported animals from the far West. A thought runs through your head - if you can capture one of these pedigree humans, your sister will love you for it.
1421.title: Felinid

14211.content:
The large male looks strong and virile, with a bulging belly that speaks greatly of its hunting prowess. While not as rare as the red-crested female, it still has the exotic pigmentation and will be able to sire plenty of healthy, human babies, which your sister will be able to sell. Rising your hiding spot, you stalk towards the target.

"What is that," the meatless one chitters, as you move slowly towards the male, claws sheathed. The humans are alert and wary, but don't yet move, frozen to the spot.

"Whatever it is, it's coming right at me," the fat one growls, hefting the knobbly branch in its hands. The sun glints of the surface of the stick, revealing what you had thought to be wood to be polished gunmetal. "Night night, kitty."

With a pneumatic *phut*, a feathered dart shoots from the end. You sidestep the projectile lazily, confused. Where had a monkey gotten its hands on a gun? Guns are so rare that you could probably list the name and owner of every one for a hundred miles. More importantly, how had such a stupid animal learned to fire one and, more pressingly, reload it.

The monkey is chambering a second dart with a purposeful, practiced motion of its stubby fingers. It raises its rifle and you do the same, squeezing the trigger. The human spasms as twin beams of coherent microwave and infra-red radiation wash over him, the baleful light cooking his insides and outsides in an instant, his boiling juices leaking out, his eyes melting, his skin charring and peeling away with a delicious meaty aroma. The underslung flachete launcher goes off with a kick. The spinning, razor-sharp strips of metal cut through him, slicing him cleanly into juicy, bite-sized chunks, which tumble onto the ground and roll across the grass, steaming wetly. You love this gun.

The female begins to shriek at the top of her lungs.
14211.title: Go for the large male

14213.content:
If you can capture and bring home the red-crested female, you know for sure your sister will love you for it. It is a fine specimen, young and healthy with fertile hips guaranteed to pop out a litter or two. Her creamy white flesh already has you salivating a little. Their faces are a little flat and their heads rather bulbous, but you suppose that's the result of the inbreeding required to produce such purebreds.

Rising out of the thick foliage to your full 9-foot height, you step into the clearing.

"What is that," the meatless one chitters, as you move slowly towards the female, claws sheathed. The humans are alert and wary, but don't yet move, frozen to the spot.

"At the risk of saying that I told you so, I'd say one of the creatures that built the roads and sent the radio transmissions," the fatter male says gleefully, its lips peeling back to show its teeth. "But hey, that's only a stone age rifle it's holding. I'm sure we're perfectly safe, right, Professor?"

"It looks like a... tiger. It's massive!"

The female takes a step back. "Why is it looking at me like that? Dave, don't just stand there, shoot it. Dave? Dave?! DAVE!"

She turns her head. The fat human has bolted and is running for the far edge of the clearing. "You're on your own, Prof!"

The female turns on her heels, sprinting after him. You bound after her excitedly, ripping up clods of earth beneath your paws. The female trips and lands hard in the dirt, and you leap for her with a victorious roar.

"Nooooooo!" The scrawny male throws himself between you and the fallen female, and tackles you, wrapping his thin arms around your torso. Aww, he's hugging you! "Run, Sam! Run! I'll hold it off as long as I can!" His tiny fists rain gentle punches against your hard, muscular abdomen. The female is still cowering on the floor. You realise the male must be attempting to protect her, unsual behaviour for humans. Normally when faced with a predator, it was every man for himself, the group of humans cattering in all directions. They would only ever stand and fight when in a defense of.... a pregnant female!

A delighted purr starts in your belly at the thought of all those adorable human babies, and you squeeze the male in your arms gleefully. His hairless skin is wonderfully smooth against your fur and you grab his head and smoosh it against your chest, the purr becoming a deep satisfied growl as his silky cheeks run over your nipples. His head buried in your six breasts, his muffled cries grow weaker "... run, Sam... get... get out of here... can't breath....can't... breath...."

He goes limp, unconscious. Your sister is always chastising you for playing too rough with her pets, but frequently you forget that they're not as resilient as cubs. You lay his sleeping form carefully on the floor, and move over to the other. Her ankle is twisted, which is why she hasn't run. She clutches it and makes weak cries of fear and pain as you crouch beside her. Gingerly lifting her and cradling her into your arms like you would a newborn cub, you begin to lick her clean, hoping to sooth her panic.
14213.title: Go for the rare, red-crested female

142131.content:
As your rough, wet tongue rasps over her smooth cheeks, she begins to quiver in your arms, her eyes wide as saucers. You stroke her vibrant red hair and pull away some of the clothing on the injured animal to nuzzle and lick at the skin of its chest and neck.

"[Please don't eat me... please don't eat me...]" it mews in your arms.

You're no human expert, but you get the impression that your gentle cleaning is having the reverse of its intended effect and scaring the poor thing. Most cubs (and one or two males) love it when you give them a once over with your tongue, evidently humans not so much.

You lay her aside carefully and return to the task at hand. It doesn't take long to discover the damage caused by the curious creatures - one of the gears connecting the turbine to the winch system has been disengaged. Slotting the machinery back together sets the thumper going again, as it begins to slowly winch the heavy weight up its column. Quickly you return to the humans - you intend to be long gone before the thumper has time to slam back down into the Earth, you'd rather not spend the rest of the day with ringing ears.

The female limping towards the edge of the clearing, hopping slowly on one leg while keeping the weight off her twisted one. It's so pathetically adorable. You sweep her into your arms, cradling her tiny form close to your chest, then sling the male over one shoulder. You set out, retracing the route you forged through the thick vegetation getting here, but soon detouring in the directions of your sister's residence. From behind, you hear the distant thud of the thumper with satisfaction.

Your sister lives in a villa of white stone, distinct for the high wall that surrounds it. The wall isn't for her protection (after all, your race has no natural predators), but to keep the pet humans locked away inside. It's the only way to keep them from wandering off.

You let yourself inside the compound. You find your sister in the garden, sprawled out on a slab of rock, sunning herself in the midday sun. In her day, she had been a terrific hunter, though these days she cares only for breeding, both of herself and her pets. Three of her cubs chase a group of humans around the garden, shouting mock hunting calls over the panicked mooing of the animals. She keeps one wary eye on their rough play, her tail twitching. She cares deeply about her pets, and has a strict no-eating rule.

The eldest cub manages to corner tackles one of the humans in the corner of the walled garden, tackling it and pinning it to the ground. It opens its salivating mouth, ready to chomp down on the tiny pink ear.

Your sister rises from the slab, fur bristling. "Hey! What did I tell you?"

"But muuuuum! It doesn't need both ears."

"No eating the humans, unless I say so. Otherwise it comes out of your pocket money."

Her daughter sulks, but lets the human go, giving it a head start before bounding after it. Your sister's ears perk up as she hears you stepping behind her. She turns, her face splitting into a broad, toothy grin. The female in your arms moans a little. "[Ah God... there's more of them...]"

"Well well. If it isn't the Great Hunter," your sister mocks. That's been her nickname for you ever since she handed the family rifle to you. Her eyes fall on the thing in your arms and she gasps in disbelief. She doesn't ask for permission, just plucks it right out of your grip. "What do we have here? Where on Earth did you find this? This breed cost a fortune."

"I thought you'd like it. A group of them were interfering with the thumpers. Any idea who they might belong to?"

"Yeah. Me," she laughs. The human yelps as she crushes it possessively to her chest. "Don't tell me you're thinking of reporting them. You know they'll only put them down if you hand them in. Let me have them. You owe me this, I gave you the rifle!"
142131.title: Next

143.content:
The Empires.

That was what the few that knew much about history called them. Most born in the generations since didn't bother learning why everything was like it was, they knew nothing else and were taught how to survive.

You, however, were different. Sure, you were good with a gun and could probably fend off a rabid dog barehanded, but what you were interested in was the past.

Chekrova and Pyortovik.

Those were the names of the two Empires.

You live in the shattered husk of a city once held by Pyortovik. It no longer had a name; it was just The City. Most of the citizen, you included, live in an underground bunker network that stretches across The City. Going outside at all was dangerous; go for a walk without any protection and you'd be cancer'd to death - if that was a real phrase - in seconds if your throat wasn't torn apart by dust.

You made a pretty good living for yourself, occasionally venturing out into the wastes in search of books that weren't completely ruined. They sold for a high price, allowing you not just your own room, but a large one at that! And with sound dampening walls, you could actually have a sleep cycle, as opposed to plugging your ears and shutting your eyes whenever you were exhausted. There was always too much noise.

Speaking of your own room, it was pretty nice. Good ventilation, a bed that didn't have shit and piss soaked into the matress, a desk and lamp so you could write using holopaper - books were easy to replicate, but getting them in the first place? A lot harder. And given how the Network's stock of literature was rather pathetic?

Well, there was a reason you were payed so well.

It's like this, you know? You got your 'pad and holopaper, you can just copy the holopaper onto the 'pad and have a permanent copy, but you needed the book in the first place.

And that was your job. Getting books.

A few of the children around the Bunker called you the Librarian. It was easy to see why, although librarians tended to check books out rather than copy and sell them.

Your possessions, like your room, were expensive. A Mortovich battery rifle - rudimentary laser rifle, unlimited battery life but needs to recharge when it runs out of juice - and a full suit of body armour, a radio and mini telescreen, some rather nice drinks, and so on.

Your respirator was also high quality. Better safe than sorry. You'd heard some poor bastard's had failed just before getting into the Bunker. Apparently he could never talk again.

You start off most days with a routine of sorts, and today is no different. Get out of bed, walk over to toilet, piss so the water recyclers let you use the taps without paying for the water, get dressed and have breakfast, then check mail.

You had mail. Probably another job. Might as well take it. You could never get too rich, after all.

So, do you want to continue this storyline, or start your own?
143.title: The Dark Earth

144.content:
Okay, here's one set of realities, and one reality to start us off:

Earth 2:
Our Earth, identical to Earth Prime save for the fact that Open Day never occured. Is gradually diverging from Earth Prime as time goes on.

Cordyceps:
We've all heard of the Cordyceps Fungi, right? You know, the one that controls ants and takes over their netvous systems in order to propagate itself? In this reality, the Cordyceps Fungi has spread across the world, controlling every last living creature.
And in the process, it has become sapient.
Each individual controlled by the fungi is still controlled by it, as the fungi is unable to relinquish control, but the thin stalks growing out of the heads of every animal on earth now act as out brains do, letting each individual fungus think and feel.
And they feel, indeed. Chief among these feelings is regret for the billions of lives they unknowingly extinguished while still just a simple fungus. But one day, when a portal opens and a human, of all things, falls through, perhaps the Cordyceps has found a chance at redemption?
144.title: More Realities

1443.content:
Okay, let's have a couple more realities!

Inquisition:
What would you do if demons turned out to be real? Scream and run around like a headless chicken, probably. Within this reality, humanity lives in fear of those that lurk in the dark, and only the Inquisition, garbed in robes of red and wielding holy weapons and purifying flame, can stand between mankind and the forces of eternal damnation...
At least, that's what mankind thinks.
Despite their appearances that range from intimidating to outright horrifying, demonkind bears humanity no ill will. It's just rather difficult to explain this when those who try to contact you are burned alive.
When out of the blue, a human appears, from another dimension, no less, will demonkind finally be able to establish peaceful contact with mankind? Or will their plan, along with so many branded as heretics by the Inquisition, go up in smoke?

Humans Are Warriors:
In this reality, which is mainly sci-fi with sprinklings of alternate history here and there, mankind has reached the stars. In fact, it did so quite a while ago. Excellent news, right?
Wrong.
Compared the peaceful inhabitants of the galaxy, mankind is bloodthirsty and psychotic beyond all units of measurement, with a few notable exceptions, who still pale in comparison to humanity's bloodlust. Despite mankind's advanced technology, the various alien species in the galaxy enforce titanic trade embargoes, territory denials, and other agreements against mankind in the hope that this bloodthirsty band of savages will crawl back into the cave they lumbered out of. Xenophobia is high, and humanity is constantly on edge, meaning it is only a matter of time before the galaxy is drowned in a red tide.
But, will the arrival of a transdimensional human change things? Can they convince the galaxy to work together? Is there an ancient threat about to emerge, the only humanity can defeat, and only with the galaxy's help?

You decide!
1443.title: More Realities!

14431.content:
Sword.
Check.
Crozier.
Check.
Wards.
Check.
Oil flask.
Check.

Pulling your hood up and over your head, you breathe in, step forward, and kick the door in front of you off its hinges with an almighty CRACK!

Striding into the dwelling, you quickly scan the home, sighting the two occupants, who were sitting at a table, about to bolt. Intercepting the man as he tries to run, tripping over his chair, out of the corner of your eyes you can see the woman running down a set of stairs into a basement. Good, she wouldn't be able to run.

Pushing the man over onto his back with a steel-shod boot, you lean down and grab his clothes at the chest, roughly lifting him up to eye legs so he could gaze through the otherwise blank faceplate into your burning azure eyes.

"Where is the demon?" You ask, your voice deadly calm. Your only answer is the stench of urine, the man too afraid to string together a sentence.

"I SAID, where is the demon?" The man still does not answer, his eyes resembling those of a rabbit being chased by a particularly large hound.

"You will be judged for this, later." Rearing your head back, you slam your forehead into his, your metal faceplate ensuring that the man was out cold.

Spreading your red robes to reveal the heavy steel armour underneath, you draw your sword and advance down the stairs into the basement.

Under your helmet, your face contorts with disgust. A summoning circle was engraved into the floor with chalk, a candle set at each of the star's points. Candles that had been hurriedly and sloppily lit by the frantic woman cowering in the corner.

Eldritch fire begins to spill forth from the circle, and you turn your attention to whatever threat was about to emerge.
A humanoid figure, its skin entirely red, materialises in the midst of the circle, the flame dissipating. Upon seeing you, the demon's face displays shock and fear.

Good. All evil should fear the Inquisition.

It was obviously a lesser demon, his appearance indicating as much. No horns, pathetic muscles, average human height, and small claws instead of fingernails.

Armour clanking, you stride towards the disgusting thing, turning as you do so, your sword in your hand. Turning on the spot, you let your sword arm travel in a horizontal arc, ripping through the demon's throat in an instant.

Regaining your balance, you watch as the now headless body thumps to the floor. You were lucky it was a lesser demon that was summoned, as even the rawest of Inquisition recruits could defeat them with the right moves. Spinning decalitations seemed to be popular.

The demon's body dissolves into a pink-red fire, returning it back to the Hell it came from. Noting the candlesticks on the summoning circle's star points, you quickly rend each of them in half, your sword easily cutting through them.

Walking over to the sobbing woman in the corner of the room, you grab her by the hair, dragging her kicking and wailing form behind you as you exit the building, pausing to sheath your sword and take hold of the male heretic's clothes. Dragging both the unconscious man and the screaming woman through the streets, you whisper to her, just loudly enough so that only she can hear.

"God may forgive all, but I'm not God. You're going to tell us everything you know; the names of your fellow cultists, where you meet, and at what times. Because I'm not God, I don't have to forgive you. And for summoning such a vile creature to this realm, endangering the lives of all in this town, just so you could fuel your sick fantasies, indulge in your disgusting desires without care for your neighbours who would be slaughtered had I not intervened?
Well, I'm not feeling particularly forgiving.
And neither is the Inquisition."
14431.title: Inquisition

144311.content:
You continue to drag the pair of degenerates through the cobbled streets, onlookers halting to scream and shout at the two. Eventually, you reach an intersection near the center of the town, and follow the route that would bring you to its center. What greets you is a makeshift platform, as well as a small pit dug into an area not covered by stones. Standing on the platform are fellow members of the Inquisition; the executioner, the judge, and a first acolyte. A large cros has gathered, cheering you on as you approach with the two heretics in your grip.

Lifting the two up by their hair, you force their gazes upwards to the judge and executioner; the man having regained consciousness as you were walking.

"We are gathered here today to witness the trial of these two heretics. The first is accused of willingly summoning a demon; and the second is accused of helping her in this endeavour. Do you have anything to say in your defense?"

The woman is silent, her voice having faded after so much wailing. The man is too terrified to speak. They know they are about to die.

"Very well, then. The demon-summoner shall be burnt at the stake, and her accomplice shall be beheaded. Do you wish to repent before you die?"

There is no response from either of them.

"So be it. Executioner, if you would assist the second acolyte and bind the hands of these heretics?"

The executioner makes his way down from the platform, carrying two lengths of rope him. Forcing both of the heretics to lie flat on the ground, the executioner binds their hands. Forcing the woman to crawl forward on her knees, you shove her into the pit, wherein lay a large volume of wood. The executioner takes a burning chunk of wood from a nearby brazier and drops it into the pit, his mask rigid and unemotional.

Ignoring both the screams of the burning woman's and the roars of the crowd, you drag the man up to the platform, the executioner following just behind. There is a shaped block of wood at the edge of the platform used in occasions such as this, it is just the right shape for a human head to fit into.

Forcing his head into the wooden block, you put your weight down on the back of his head as he begins to struggle. The crowd, having grown bored with the dead woman, turns their attention to you and the executioner.

"Executioner, if you would take the second acolyte's blade..."

The executioner does so, the sword making a sharp shing! as it is removed from its scabbard.

The executioner raises the blade high before swinging downwards in an overhead arc. He cleanly slices the the heretic's neck, and you hold the head in the air for the crowd to gaze upon.

"BEHOLD! The rate of all evildoers!"

The crowd erupts into a frenzy of cheers, screams, and howls. There is a slight buzzing sensation in the back of your skull, but you ignore the feeling.

It takes almost an hour for the crowd to disperse. Both bodies were incinerated, their ashes cast into the wind.

You walk back to the Monastery, the headquarters of the Inquisition. Passers by cheer you as you walk. That annoying buzzing sensation returns for a brief time, but it vanishes soon enough.

All in all, an excellent day for the forces of Good, and a terrible one for the forces of Evil.
144311.title: Cleansing Flame

14432.content:
"During my time on Earth, I witnessed what I can only adequately describe as a battle, of sorts. Two different sides - one wearing white clothes with a red cross emblazoned on both the front and back, the other wearing blue clothes with a diagonal white cross - repeatedly charged at each other, trying to gain territory with a set area. At first, I thought that these humans were training the participants to be warriors, but as I watched, I noticed an elliptical ball of sorts being carried, thrown about, and kicked - it was a sport! Eventually, one of the humans wearing white and red penetrated the other side's lines while carrying the ball, slamming into the ground when reaching a white line that had been hastily marked before the beginning of the game.

Speaking with some of the participants afterwards, I learned that such games were a common occurrence, and a way of staying fit. Several of the participants seemed to be highly critical of a different variant of the sport - this one being named 'Rugby', the variant being 'American Football' - for reasons I did not initially understand. The reasons turned out to be both social and cultural, to a degree.

The nation where I was staying at the time was named, as you should recall, England - an island nation several thousand years old that at one point dominated most of Earth before slowly declining as time went on, but still remaining a major power due to its wealth and military. The other nation, America - or to be more accurate, the United States of America - England being part of the United Kingdom - was once an English colony that successfully rebelled against English rule, fighting several wars against them before the two slowly became the steadfast allies that they are today.

The reasons for the criticality seemed to be both a combination of, and I quote, "Americans not knowing the definition of the word foot", suggesting some mild jingoism, and bizzarely, the use of padded armour in American Football. The several broken bones I witnessed during the game of Rugby would seem to suggest that the use of armour was a very good idea indeed, but I was assured that broken bones were common in both sports. Given how my species possesses no bones, I would be rather keen to make sure mine would stay undamaged, if I was a vertebrate."

Smiling slightly, you bookmark the page you were reading on your holopad, before setting it down, standing up, and stretching, hearing several bones crack and pop. You had been to Earth before, and it seemed like a nice place to live. Maybe when you worked up enough credits you could have another holiday there.

You lived on Viaso, a multispecies hub planet - a combination of a planet spanning city and a massive spaceport. At least you had an apartment to yourself. It was a rather nice one, as well - cool blue lighting suiting the steel grey walls, and high quality fittings, furniture and mod-cons meant that it was brilliantly easy to unwind and relax.

Perhaps you could go out for a bit. You had agreed to meet Terax later. Terax was a Vulthoor, an insectoid race sharing humanity's reputation for violence. There were differences, however, differences between the two races. Humanity was almost naturally suited for modern combat - bipedal, with two hands; fast and able to take punishment; and adrenaline and endorphins essentially made humans the perfect shock troops. However, most humans were not suited for combat, despite what many aliens claimed, as they were mentally or physically unfit, the first being the most common reason - it was one thing to have the ability to kill someone, but it was another thing to be able to do so without suffering major psychological trauma. Many human soldiers were only able to be in such a career because of adrenaline, that wonderful drug turning meek and quiet men and women into rabid killing machines on the battlefield.

Vulthoor, on the other hand, were quadrupedal insectoid with a single pair of arms. While not as strong or fast as humans in general, Vulthoor were steady on their feet; possessed natural spikes running along the outer sides of their arms, and above all else, were able to be disciplined and trained to degrees that would make many human soldiers weep.

In short, Humans were the primal warriors of the galaxy, and the Vulthoor were the soldiers of the galaxy.

You and Terax often chatted over drinks in the local pub, or whatever the word for it was in the various alien languages. One topic he was particularly interested in was human weaponry, the Vulthoor having recently found footage of different tanks throughout human history on the extranet. Brave patriots, risking all to sabotage vital enemy supply lines, preventing the enemy's weapons, ammunition, armour and more, from ever reaching him.

And the rest of the galaxy averted their gazes, quietly forming pacts, enforcing sanctions, attempting to unite against humanity and generally being rather slow about it - such was the nature of politics, after all.

Growling happily and quietly, you lean back in your chair, enjoying your surroundings. Your ship, The Theremin as it was currently known, was essentially a civilian cruise ship converted into a warship. That meant lots of space. Space that could be used to store 'liberated' cargo. Space that could be used to give each crewmember their own cabin. Space that could be used to hide guns and missile launchers until the right moment, when they would emerge from their hiding places on your ship and unleash a broadside, or a salvo, or whatever firing pattern you wanted.

Your cabin - the captain's cabin - looked like the inside of a twenty first century hotel room; the economic use of space, the pleasing colours, the simple and subtle elegance that many seem to miss.

Fiddling with your datapad, you check the estimated time it would take to travel back to Terra; you were still several hours out. Still, you'd had an excellent catch with the last raid. Intercepting enemy gun-runners was always profitable, especially when they were supporting the vorox, and especially when the Solar League was at war. You'd crippled the ship while in the gravity well of a large garden planet, managing to destroy the engines. Quickly ordering the crew to their bidding pods, you'd made quick estimates on the ship's remaining time in orbit before joining them, travelling across in your own pod as the pods already attached were slowly winched back, pulling the enemy ship closer and closer to your own.

You had allowed them to take some of the food that your men hadn't raided. 1443322.content:
The idea here is a post-apocolyptic Earth...with one VERY big twist. It wasn't what we built for war that brought about the end, it was what, and who, we created; for simple recreation. The worlds of fiction and reality collided, and both were changed forever...

====

It's truly a fucked-up world when the phrase "Use your imagination" is considered a curse. No, not "curse" as in profanity; "Curse" as in an invocation of misfortune, calling for fate to bring its wrath upon them...

Ahem...I'll start at the beginning, as it were.

Our world was once a lot like yours, this "Earth Prime" I've heard about. Not an exact copy, of course--just look through a few books and you can pick out differences of all sizes. Where we break off the most, though?

I'll just come out and say it: "OUR reality wasn't that separate from OUR fiction. Yeah, so the fourth wall broke, and its rubble buried us.

It started small--sightings of a certain blue phone booth in Egypt one day; rumors of "strange animals" in Japan the next. The usual "man-bites-dog" stories on the news, or conspiracy-theorist drivel; nothing to concern yourself with. God in Heaven, were we wrong....

Then, it got bigger, stranger: "Vigilantes with unknown weapons" showing up and stopping a shooting or bank robbery; ships vanishing without a trace in perfectly safe waters...usually right after some sighting of a "giant squid" or some-such thing. And behind the scenes the "Contacts" started--artists, authors, fucking cartoonists--anyone who'd created, or helped create, a famous fictional character or world would start getting messages from their characters. A phone call, a letter slipped under the door...or a goddamn green ring, in one poor sap's case. I still don't know if it worked for him or not.

Things kept building up--those weird stories and sightings kept happening more, and getting worse...until the Emergence.

March 18, 2025. That was the day 'imagination' became a curse. Every character, every hero and villain, ever single monster and madman we ever cooked up to entertain ourselves was let loose on the world. Marines fought Stormtroopers in Los Angeles. Sauron and his Uru'Kai overran Berlin and set up shop there, with the rest of Germany torn between the Enclave and HYDRA. I once saw two twentysomething punks with R's on their shirts take down a whole mob with their pet snake and a rocket launcher back in Vegas.

China...is just gone. God, you can still hear the "Exterminate!" echoes in what's left of Bejing...!

So that's the long-and-short of it. Somehow, the barrier between reality and fiction crumbled, leaving both worlds wide open. We--the "Reals", as you'll hear some of us call ourselves--weren't wiped out when the "Fictions" poured in. Some of us fought, others hid,some even worked together with the Fictions to fight off their enemies. Strange bedfellows and whatnot.

Hardly anything left of the old, "Real" world now--cities that haven't been wiped off the map have been rebuilt, nothing like what they were before. Places that we called paradise are now warzones, or just to dead to even fight over. Hell, even some of our old wastelands are now packed to the gills! Just look at the Atacama--if you can get in, of course. I hear these "Foundation" guys will do ANYTHING to keep a secret. When they say "Secure" or "Contain", they mean it. I haven't seen them "Protect" anyone but themselves, though.

Here's hoping you can make some sense of this clusterfuck of a world. We sure couldn't, and still can't.

There wasn't a single face in the village that stayed home. All the workers freighting up the cars ignore you as you stand before the open door of the train, scrutinizing every face staring at you for any hint of emotion at the step you were about to make past the threshold of our small, ever dwindling sense of reality. They're all invested, sure, but you can't weed out a soul who remotely veers towards any extreme of the empathic line, whether it be supportive or fearful of your dilemma.

Along the roofs of the empty box cars, all of the town's top muscle'd been scrounged up to sit around and keep watch, ready with everything; guns, knives, molotov cocktails, hairspray cans and lighters, rocks, bricks, and even pressurized hoses and toy squirt guns, their tanks filled with horrific-smelling mixtures of turpentine, acetone, and benzine. Anything that, as far as during the good old days before the great merge'd split the world of sanity in half, had a knack for hurting any kind of species that you'd throw it at.

Those days were long gone, however, a thought that makes you let loose a long, unstable sigh.

You turn to gaze down the train's nose, observing the curves in the track ahead. The boundary to toon territory lay just a few hundred feet away, only obscured by the fall-stripped forest, but unlike some bouncy neighborhood filled with sapient buildings, trees, and woodland creatures all singing some jaunty musical number about how wonderful life was, the cartoon realm just looked...dead. Felt dead, too, somehow even more dead than the rules and cynicism of reality, with all the foliage clearly stripped of its life and color as the dawn of winter started rearing its head.

Were a few tanks of gas really that worth it?

"Hank?"

You snap back to Jim, who's seated in his spot at the engine's cab, his hand already on the throttle. "Yeah?"

"S'time."

If there was ever any sound from the crowd observing the train's assembly, it was all gone, now. Everybody, Hank, the train's gunmen, and all the villagers are dead quiet as they all turn their head at you, the last obstacle keeping the train from leaving.

You take the rail along the door's opening, but only to keep yourself upright as you raise a foot, staring intently down at the very first step into the train's cab. Your legs' muscles grow tired from the motionless workout, jittering around in the air, but you don't give it relief. You just stand still, cherishing the absolute last seconds of reality you have left before the moment the lottery, all the briefings, and all the assemblies'd been amounting too.

When the weight of your leg is too much to bear, just as Jim's mouth opens to say something, you step onto the train's floor. You take the next step. And the next. And the next, increasingly filled with regret by each you pass.

Soon, without even remembering sitting down, you're in the seat next to Jim's, and the door's been slid shut.

"Ready?"

You don't answer. Even if his hand's already on the lever, you grab the throttle, gently easing it forward. Beneath the floors, the engine's wheels grind forward, and slowly, but with a very subtle increase in speed, the train and its cars lurch away from the end of the station, submerging itself into the leaf-covered hills of the forest...

"So, what if a textbook on history got a fact or two wrong, or something?" Jim asks aloud. "Would that make the guy they were talking about fictional? Would that mean they're running around somewhere out there, too?"

Even if he's trying to speak in a light tone, you're not listening. The entire trip, for all of eight hours and into the full birth of nighttime, you'd kept your eyes set on the track, steeling yourself to call the cannons on any blip of a bright color that'd dart in your way, and all of Jim's attempts to muster up a conversation fall on deaf ears.

The only part of you that isn't ready to pull a trigger is very thinly curious at the scenery that lay beyond the town's circle, which was all left to grow for many decades without being grazed by man. The train passes by many empty canyons, rivers and mountains, all of them too far away to be seen by anything but a telescope from where you'd lived, and it's a miracle the track still even exists enough to allow such a smooth journey after all the years of rain and sleet it must've lived through.

It's rather unnerving, really, but nowhere near as unnerving as the utter lack of animation to be seen whisking around through the trees. Worst of all was when the sun began setting, and all the shadows, branches, and other little details of the world were slowly melded into silhouettes. Jim's tone became a little more jittered as the light of day was noticeably leaving the sky,

By the time the sun was gone, all the world was black, save for two stripes of rail ahead that were reflected by the headlights.

"...shit."

At last, I proved I wasn't catatonic and cricked my head an inch to the left, looking Jim's way. He looked down at the readout of the train's tanks with a look of rapidly waning hope, particularly at a dial that was quickly decreasing.

"I asked them!" He growled, punching the dashboard. "I fucking asked them if they said the fuel hoses were all hooked on properly! They said yes!"

"Well, what're we supposed to do?" I replied, whatever resolve I had left fading away.

"We've gotta stop, is what we've got to do!" He answered, his hand going for the brake, but I grabbed his wrist.

"You expect us to go outside? At..." I pointed at the blackout beyond the window. "Into that?!"

He looked like he was taking my question into heart, truly asking it to himself, over and over, but he still pulled the brake down.

As he let the whir of the engine die out, I turned back ahead, hitting a button on the intercom. "Engine to freight line, we're making a stop. I repeat, we're making a stop due to fuel maintenance. Stay on guard as we exit the train."

And the, for the most tortuous five minutes I'd ever felt pass by, we sat and waited, unable to do anything as we were forced to watch the train let itself stop, the cars' momentum keeping us in motion. Out the windows, I could see a glimmer of light from the mirrors as some of the gunmen manned their posts, but I could feel a twinge of terror in the pit of my heart tell me that anything they could've done would just be one big reassurance. Even worse was when the train, with the last errant of speed from its trip, still hung around at a person's walking pace for the damnedest length of time I would've thought possible. Jim had his eyes on the fuel tank the whole time, silently begging for there to be a half of our tank left when we'd stopped.

He'd lost all interest in the readout, though, when his head snapped up to the window. "What was that?"

"What was what?"

His head darted another way. This time, I saw it. A little murmur of movement somewhere in all the darkness, even if it was all in pitch black. We kept our heads up as our hands went to the glove compartments of our seats, the both of us in perfect harmony as we pull ourselves each a gun, pulling back the hammer.

Pointing the barrels at the bulletproof windshield, we tried to weed out as much of the forest as there was to be seen, ignoring the sweat dripping along our heads as we saw the shape of the movement become more pronounced under the headlights' glare...

You blink, focusing your vision.

In front of you is a scientists, one employed by the Corporation that created you. He checks his syringes and his machines, tryig not to look nervous. "Now, T-Two-Six-Nine, if you could place the blood pressure cuff on your arm..." You do so, and he starts the test, repeating it to form a baseline for your blood pressure. "Just m-making s-sure that everything's working p-properly..." God, this one was annoying. All the scientists were insufferable in their own ways, but this nervous wreck was beginning to seriously get on your nerves.

The scientist holds a syringe between his trembling fingers, which slips from his grasp and shatters on the floor. Laughing nervously, the scientists mops the sweat at his brow away with a hand. "Heh, I guess I'd better get another one of those..." And with that, the man all but runs to the door of your cell, stumbling on the way there. Slamming his ID card down on the panel needed to open the door, he sprints through the heavy metal door as the thick metal slab retracts into the wall, slamming shut behind him. Several more layers of metal come down after it, filling the deep doorframe with various sheets of metal and preventing escape. A growling sigh escapes your throat.

This... Corporation... was utterly disgusting. They created humans, bred and raised them for combat, and then sold them to different militarise around the world. Hades, Mars, Sol, Falcon. These names had been stolen, and given to different Lines.

What is a Line? you think to yourself, remembering the day when you asked the question. A product line.

Hades; the assassination and stealth Line. Made to sneak into areas and past fortifications, silently killing key person el as they went.

Mars; the demolition Line. Armed with RPGs and grenade launchers, they could bust any bunker.

Sol; the infantry killing Line. Armed with white hot flamethrowers and napalm grenades, any biological matter near a Sol would be scorched and burnt to ashes by the time she was done.

Falcon; the pilot and reconnaissance Line. Either flying a plane or scouting enemy territory, Falcons seemingly never stopped moving for more than a moment.

All of these Lines and more; little more than fleshy puppets, mindless drones to be controlled by rich officers and generals who did not care for the lives of their men.

Well, there was the odd sapient Line. They were bent and broken, indoctrinated into serving the Corporation, serving as sergeants and leaders for their entire lives. Issuing orders to unthinking killing machines for their entire lives, and loving every second of it.

Then there was you.

Apex. The Ultimate Line. The Zenith. The true meaning of the word killing machine. The product of decades of genetic experimentation.

Subject Two-Six-Nine; Property of The Corporation; Apex Line Prototype Alpha; Approximate Value: Incalculable.

At least, that was what the ID tattoo on your back said.

Lines weren't just for combat, though. There were servant Lines, surgeon Lines, accountant Lines... And they all had that same blank stare, as if their brains were trying to grant them the tiniest fragment of free will, but utterly failing.

That being said, the combat Lines were definitely the moneymakers. You could extrapolate that from the list of combat Lines alone. Each combat Line had a specific role on the battlefield, from taking out enemy infantry to scouting - those roles belonging to Sol and Falcon, although there were other, less popular Lines that fulfilled these roles.

Your role was to destroy everything in sight.

More or less.

Pain tolerance that would shame even a bio-mech? Check.
Extreme muscle mass in certain areas, such as the legs and arms, allowing you to jump several times your own height and shatter bones with a single punch? Check.
Bones dense enough to serve as armour underneath your skin, such as your nigh-impenetrable ribs, which had been fused together into a single, sternum-like mass? Check.
Muscles strong enough to offset the extreme weight all of this caused? Check.
An almost in red familiarity and expertise with all standard issue Corporation weapons and weapons systems? Check.

And to top it off, fucking psychic powers?

You were made to take down entire squads. Entire platoons. By yourself. Entire armies, with other Lines in support and protecting you.

You were literally made for war.

But war was not something you desired, despite the hyper aggressive urges your over reactive adrenal system sent you. An eternity of war, with no end until you were killed by something, most likely a nuke? No. Please, no.

If you could, you'd hide away someplace remote. Normal people wouldn't want to know the limits that their genome could be twisted to; they'd call you an abomination. Living on your own with nothing to disturb you would be... Ideal.

And yet, here you were, trapped in a tiny cell with a seven inch thick metal door, your patience being tested a little more with each passing day. You had to get out, somehow. Even if you had to kill to accomplish it, you had to get out. You weren't gonna be a slave. You weren't gonna be a little toy, paraded about and tossed around along with your unthinking brothers and sisters into different battles until you finally expired and your genetic material was used to remake you.

You weren't gonna be some military's trump card unless you wanted to be. Not unless inaction would be worse than action.

As far as the Corporation was concerned, you weren't a person. You never would be. You were a weapon; a Weapon of Mass Destruction on par with an atomic bomb, and infinitely more expensive.

You weren't going to be that. Kill a few hundred to escape and live in solitude for as long as possible, or stay and kill thousands upon thousands as you were forced into different war zones by your neglectful and abusive creators?

But how would you escape?

Perhaps...

Perhaps, you could kill that scientist. Rip his ID card from his fingers. Tear through your birthplace, destroying it from within. Escape into the world. Feel the Sun on your skin. The grass under your feet. The calm peace of solitude as you live your life. Away. From the Corporation. Kill any of them that come close. Rip their arms out. Tear them in two. GRAB THEIR SPINE AND RIP THEIR SKULL OUT THROUGH THEIR CHEST! BREAK EVERY BONE IN THEIR FUCKING BODIES! STOMP THEM INTO DUST! REND THEM APART AND SMASH THEM INTO PIECES!

You barely register the clamps holding you in place, the voice saying "The new synthetic adrenaline was more effective than we could have imagined. How did he not notice the doctor returning to his room, though?", the cocktail of general anaesthetic drugs pulling you into peaceful sleep, and you barely even register the human shaped portal appearing out of nowhere, a small squad of heavily armed soldiers securing the room, lining the Corporation scum up against the wall as they eye your raging form, demanding an answer that the cowardly doctors cannot bring themselves to give, vanishing back through the portal, which closes just before you finally drop off into peaceful, drug-fuelled sleep.

Your eyes open in an instant, your body alert despite having awoken mere seconds ago. You can only see blackness in front of you, and you can feel metal clamps tightly holding your arms and legs in place. Leaning your head forward, you feel it connect with a metal surface. Leaning it to the sides gives the same results.

You had been placed in a small holding cell, from the way things seemed. You had been held in these cells many times before, often in an attempt to get you to stop asking questions. While you had physically aged quite quickly, your mind had taken time to catch up, and the Corporation tried to capitalise on that fact by attempting to indoctrinate you to their whims. One memory from your childhood - if it could be called that - was having the book 1984 read to you by one of the researchers. Of course, it was heavily edited, and the morality flipped; total obedience, privacy destroying surveillance, and unending conflict had been portrayed as good things in the bastardised version some Corporation monkey had shat out of a typewriter that would have had Orwell simultaneously rolling and spontaneously combusting in his grave.

You weren't exactly sure how old you were - never leaving the same set of rooms for your entire existence, coupled with having to manually count sleep cycles tended to destroy one's sense of time - but if you had to hazard a guess, you'd say you were about nine or ten years old. The Corporation wanted a super-soldier, and they wanted one ASAP.

"It appears that some of our... rivals, have developed a teleportation system..."

Straining your hearing, you manage to eavesdrop on the conversation being held outside your tiny cell.

"What are we going to do? If they can teleport inside our bases then they can steal or destroy anything they want!"
"They weren't rivals! Their armour had no insignias on it that belonged to any other Corp!"
"Terrorists, perhaps?"
"No. They were too well armed."
"A government Black Ops group?"
"I don't think so. Most depend on us for their soldiers, after all."
"What do you think we should do if they come back?"
"Most Lines would be too stupid to use their own communication equipment, and we have no idea how strong they are so regular humans are out of the question."
"Are you saying-"
"Yes, he is."
"Are you mad?!"
"No, I'm not. The board of directors has already authorised Two-Six-Nine's usage."
"YOU WANT TO USE A WMD!"
"Be that as it may, he can destroy the competition and then return. I think it'll be a good test of his combat capabilities in the field; as I have already said, the board agrees with me."
"... Fine. You talk with the brute, I'm leaving. If you need me, I'll be drinking something strong."

The door in front of you quickly slides into the wall and your clamps release your arms and legs. Falling to your hand and knees, you then stand and roll your shoulders. "So you need me for something, boss?" you say, putting on a fake smile. "Yes, Two-Six-Nine." We need you to be ready in case of another incursion into this Corporation facility. If there is, enter the portal, gauge enemy strength, and eliminate if possible."

This could be your way out. You could play these scientists, letting them think they had you under their control until you entered the portal and destroyed your communications equipment, never returning. And if the portal and armed men didn't return, then it was only a matter of time before you busted yourself out of the facility anyway.

"Alright, boss. Gimme a shout if you need me."
Passing the two scientists, you leave the room through the metal bulkhead, a pair of guard tailing you until you arrive back in your room. A simple bed lay in one corner of the bland room, a small table of faux-wood beside it. A miniature computer/tablet device lay on the table, allowing you access to the Internet. The Corporation had tried to limit what you saw on it, but you had hacked your way past the filters long ago, and the Corporation, in their arrogance, had never bothered to see if their filters had actually worked.

All in all, the Corporation had done a pretty pisspoor job at indoctrinating you.

Laying on your bed, you stare up at the blank, sterile, white ceiling. Snorting, you find yourself bored, and with a lack of things to do, you close your eyes and allow yourself to fall asleep until your body decides that it is time to wake up.

Perhaps something interesting would happen when you awoke.

You awake once again, a slight smile on your lips. One way or another, you would be leaving. Eyeing a small clock mounted on the wall opposite where your bed lay, you noted the time: 00:23. Good, pretty much all personnel would be asleep andrying on automated security, with the exception of a few guards at important checkpoints.

Inhaling, then exhaling, you look down at your body. Your skin was extremely pale, on account of never having been outside before. Feeling your sides, instead of being able to feel individual ribs and the slight gaps between them like a normal prrson would, you feel one thick mass of bone protecting your vital organs, dense enough to serve as subdermal armour.

Cracking your neck, you stand up and walk over to the other side of your rather spartan room. Touching a small panel on the wall results in a small section seperating to allow you access to a wardrobe behind it. You exchange your clothes for fresh ones, pulling on a vest, pants and trousers. Touching the panel to conceal the wardrobe again, you open a different section of the wall to reveal a smaller wardrobe.

The Corporation could be truly idiotic at times, in addition to the usual arrogance. One example of this idiocy was leaving your armour in your bedroom. It takes nearly ten minutes to put all of your armour on, minus your helmet. Eyeing the CCTV camera mounted directly above your bed, you begin to stretch your leg muscles, Moving on to your arms before doing several sets of jumping jacks.

You had been planning this for a long time. One thing you had thought up was to irregularly wake up at extremely late/early times, put on new sets of clothes and your armour, and then do several sets of stretches. This way, anyone viewing you through the security camera would not immediately go into panic mode upon seeing you pull on your armour, which would have resulted in a facility-wide lockdown. Granted, you'd still be able to bust your way out, but it would be much more inconvenient.

Using your telekinetic powers to force the security camera to sweep left and right, back and forth - mimicking a security camera glitch that forces it to adhere to a basic area scanning protocol, often causing the person manning the camera to briefly leave the monitoring station to find a troubleshooting guide - you stare at the control panel mounted on the wall next to the seven inch thick series of metal slabs that served as the door to your room.

You were under curfew, as always. No leaving your room from 22:45 to 08:00. You weren't going to let that stop you though. And since hacking was out of the question, because the panel had been locked down as part of the curfew...

... Well, subtlety was boring anyway!

Jamming the security camera in place while it looks away from you, you gather your powers. Seven inches would be an inconvenience, but not enough to stop you. Clenching your fist, you drag it towards you, slowly ripping the series of metal slabs out of the doorframe. Jerking it towards you violently, you smirk as an automated alarm sounds and the slabs loudly crash onto the floor, most warped heavily.

Stepping through the doorframe and pulling your helmet on, you enter the corridor connecting your room to the rest of the facility, walking at a brisk pace. Thankfully, only your door was locked. While it would have been fun to rip every bulkhead and door out of their frames, it would have allowed the Corporation to assemble their squads of Lines, which would have been inconvenient.

Taking a left, then a right, and another right, you quickly make your way through the facility, ripping through any locked doors you encounter. Coming to an atrium, you see a small line of Corporation guards shifting nervously and aiming their weapons at you, eight or so in total. At some order over their radios, they open fire, most bullets missing you as you close in towards them.

Gripping two in your telekinesis, you smash them into the walls, denting the surfaces slightly and leaving a crimson smear across the steel surface. Using your telekinesis to grab one by the head, you lift him into the air slightly before slamming him face first into the floor, breaking his skull.

Three down, five to go. Yanking one guard's rifle out of his grasps even as the other fire again, you manipulate it in midair, ramming the butt of the weapon into his chin. Four more to go. Crushing their weapons into small balls of metal as you run, mere metres away, you can't help but sneer under your helmet as they panic, yelling obscenities. Seeing that one has a combat knife tucked into digging around his hips, you lift it into midair as you halt, then send it right at his throat. Three more.

One of them charges at you, flailing with his fists in a case of suicidal overconfidence. Thrusting your open palm forward, the guard is propelled into a wall, his back snapped and cracked in several places. The two remaining are trying to run but have seized up, so you simply elect to manipulate their forms, holding them in midair and ramming their helmets together, knocking them both out cold with possible concussions.

Breaking into a sprint, you run past the gory display and into another network of corridors. You move on instinct, turning his way and that, ripping bulkheads apart with ease. Nothing will stop you. Nothing can stop you. Nothing can stop you.

You come to another atrium, this one much, much larger than the last. A huge set of blast doors are opposite you, as well as a veritable wall of guards with a variety of weapons. There must be at least thirty.

They are standing between you and those doors. Between you and your freedom. These Corporation whores will either step aside or be thrown aside.

A roar escaping from your throat, you charge again, closing the gap as the guards open fire. This time, they manage to hit you, bullets bouncing off your armour as you sprint across the almost entirely nondescript room. Corporate didn't care about aesthetics, after all. Exit here, space here, corridor there; no need to spend money making it look nice and pretty.

Clenching your left fist and sweeping. It to the side, ten of the guards and tossed like rag dolls through the air, many impacting the steel walls; others are simply flung through the air, painfully meetin the ground seconds later. You can't be more than thirty feet from the great blast doors, now. You know what to do, somehow.

Fuelled by your rage, a telekinetic blast sweeps out in front of you, floor panels being ripped and flung into the air as it goes. It meets the blast doors, metal squealing as it gives way, shuddering and rending into a you-sized hole. You widen it as you run, sparing a glimpse at the remaining guards to you right; there were twenty or so remaining. A sweeping gesture is all it takes to send them all up to the ceiling, most dying instantly as their skulls are crushed.

Laughing, you run through the tear in the blast doors.

You can see light. Actual light. Natural light. For the first time. Resealing the gap you had ripped in the blast door, you allow yourself a few second to gaze up at the moon. Gods, god, whatever, it was beautiful. Turning your attention to your surroundings, you look around. A large Tarmac road cut through what seemed to be a small jungle or forest of sorts. You can almost smell the freedom. It was a good thing that Lines barely have to eat or drink, and can eat or drink almost anything, because you didn't bring any supplies with you. Taking in one of your first breaths of natural air, savouring the warmth and humidity, you prepare to run, and never look back...

"Oh, bollocks!"

Hearing a soft snort from behind you, you turn around to see your pet horse, Blaze, giving you a deadpan stare.

"Oh shuddup."

The black mare smiles slightly.

"I never said anything."

Blaze's voice was odd, like someone had taken the snorts, whinnies, and neighs she used to converse with other horses, and them warped that into a voice. Due to the strange link that humanity shared with a wide range of animals, however, you could understand her instinctively.

"You were giving me that look again."

Blaze flicks her ears, giggling softly.

"Was not."

You grin.

"Was too."

Blaze's smile widens.

"Was not."

Blaze allows you to re-mount her back, settling into a slow trot. "Are you okay? Besides the muddy clothes and everything? I don't think you've fallen like that in quite a while." Leaning forward slightly, you gently scratch the top of the black mare's head. "I'll be fine, I've probably only got a bruise from it."

Blaze continues to slowly trot back towards the farmhouse, hooves smothering grass underfoot. Suddenly, something in the corner of your eye catches your attention. Telling Blaze to stop, you dismount and turn to get a better look at whatever it was that you had seen.

What seemed to be a silhouette of a person hung in midair, an actual person standing a few feet away. Before you can process this bizarre scene, several more people emerge from the silhouette, most of them carrying guns. They are close enough to you that you can see that their attention is on you, and they begin to walk towards you.

Gulping, you turn to Blaze. Just what the hell was going on? Was it a top-secret military project? And invasion? Something else entirely?

"Blaze?"
"Y-yes?"
"Run. I'm... I'm going to see what they want."

Blaze swallows a lump in her throat and nods, nuzzling you before turning and galloping back to the farmhouse and stables.

Looking back at the mysterious figures, you can see that they are no more than thirty feet from you now.

Taking in a deep breath, you begin to walk towards them.

144332222211.content:
Steadying your breathing, you ball your fingers into fists to stop them from shaking. The six figures continue their slow, cautious advance, two of them sweeping their rifles this way and that, looking for possible threats. Swallowing, you begin to walk towards them as the thundering of Blaze's hooves fades in the distance.

As you and the group converge, the one who you assume to be a leader lowers his rifle, pointing it at the ground. The armour they were wearing was like nothing you'd ever seen before; what seemed to be a Kevlar jacket of some sorts was overlaid with interlocking plates of some kind that covered the chest, groin, elbows, and knees. The helmet the leader wore seemed to have a respirator of some kind built in, judging by the noise of the person's breathing. The glass-like faceplate of the grey helmet was too dark to allow you to see through, however, sort of like a motorbiker's helmet.

The other five members of the group come to a halt, lowering their weapons but staying alert.


"Civilian, can you tell us where we are?"

You visibly wince as the leader's distorted, tinny voice booms out of his helmet. Evidently, they were using some kind of vocoder.

"Uh, England... If you need specifics then I guess I can j-just get you my m-map..."

You swallow again, barely managing to keep ahold of yourself.

"Uh, could I enquire as to why you are here? Uh, I'll understand if it's classified, b-but I'd appreciate it..."

"We can tell you, but I think we'd prefer to go inside first. That way, we can have some privacy. Also, you will probably want to contact some level of government."

"O-okay, then. If you'd f-f-"

You scowl in frustration, your nerves momentarily getting the better of you.

"Ahem; if you'd follow me?"

With that, you begin to walk back to your house, the group of soldiers in tow. They seemed to be rather paranoid, constantly scanning their surroundings for any hostiles. Frankly, you couldn't really think of any potential hostiles on a small farm besides pests.

It doesn't take long for the farmhouse to come into view again. A semi-awkward silence had settled over the group the moment you had begun to escort the group to your house, allowing you to do some thinking.

The portal was an absolute mystery, but what with science today being what it was, who knew what was possible? The group didn't seem to have any insignia on their armour, and the fact that the leader requested that you attempt to inform someone in some level of government suggested something rather hush-hush goin on. Perhaps a trial of some new teleportation technology had thrown them off mark somewhat? Perhaps it had worked, but they did not have the means to communicate with the army themselves?

Your ears pick up a rapid, muted thumping off in the distance, the sound rapidly growing louder. Smiling, you see Blaze galloping towards you at full pelt, two other horses following her; you couldn't tell who they were from such a distance, but you could see that they were a deep brown and a bright white, at least. You'd have to identify them when they got close.

The trio of horses slow into a trot as they draw closer, the tensing of their muscles showing their desire to ensure your well being being overridden somewhat by their apprehension at the imposing figures behind you, most of whom were a good few inches taller than your height of five foot ten.

As Blaze and the other equines close the gap between you and them, you are able to identify the two other horses. The white one was a mare named Breeze; she was rather gentle, and usually very kind to the other animals. However, if she knew someone was in danger, wouldn't hesitate to take action. The brown horse was a stallion named Jack; he was usually rather laid back, although that didn't stop him from working hard. Unease was evident in both the eyes and body language of the trio.

Blaze's trio reaches you, the black mare sighing gratefully as she sees you are not harmed in any way. You can hear the soldiers muttering to each other, most likely sizing the three up.

"Don't worry, you three, I'm alright. These guys don't mean any harm, as far as I can tell."

You can just about hear two of the soldiers whisper to each other - suggesting the vocoder a could be turned on and off - "Is he trying to talk to those horses? Maybe in this reality they can-"

"We were so worried about you!"

Before you can respond, you're almost bowled over by the combined nuzzles of the three horses, having to steady yourself as Blaze practically launches herself at you. Hugging the tall black mare around her thick neck, you stifle a giggle as her neck and head droop over your shoulder, the adrenaline working its way out of her system. Almost instantly, the other two are adding their own nuzzles to the hug-of-sorts, relieved beyond measure that you're safe. "Like I said, I'm safe. I - I appreciate the concern, mares - and stallion - I really do..."

A scant few metres away, as the soldiers watch the scene before them unfold, two specific ones are quietly whispering to each other, their vocoders off. "Looks like we found the reality with the talking animals. About time, too. Now, how much do you owe me, again?"

Short, stunted, grey skin, large heads, weak limbs, baleful gaze.

Abductors?

Horse. Friend. Fast, strong, carry humans and pull equipment. Hooves shatter armour and crush body inside. Old allies.
Wasp. Friend? Hive animal. Swarms. Overwhelm enemies. Clouds of thousands. Stingers pierce flesh and armour. Enemy of enemy. Enemy of enemy is friend. Friend. New allies.
Snake. Friend? Reptile. Venom corrodes metal, fangs pierce metal. New allies.

You frown at the information you know about those companion-species that worked alongside you.

So many questions.

Why were they companions? Why were some old allies, and some new? Why did their physical power seem wrong, as if they had not always been so strong?

This armour, alien, this weapon, alien. This weapon, familiar. This one, kinetic, that one, plasma. This material, familiar. This environment, familiar, that one alien, another, unknown.

An ancient species, dark and mysterious, enemy to all other life. Enemy to Hivemind is enemy to all life. All life must... should... Must fight against enemy of Hivemind.

Enemy of Hivemind is dark. Is black. Is Shadow. Hivemind is Light, burns away Darkness. All Shadow must burn.

Why were you repeating this to yourself? You knew the Shadow was evil. It was the enemy to the Hivemind, the enemy to all species that were not the Shadow. Perhaps it was good to be reminded of your purpose. That way you would not fail when you next took the fight to the Shadow, alongside the Hivemind and the many species contained within.

The Shadow shall burn.

The Shadow will burn.

The Shadow must burn.

Underneath the black carapace of your helmet, you lick your dried lips. In your hands is a rifle, vat-grown to your exact specifications. It was ugly, but beautiful at the same time. Ugly to an outside observer, but beautiful to those who could appreciate the work and progress it represented.

The rifle in question was alive, as was your armour, and a fair portion of the building. Some things were simply easier or more reliable with technology rather than bio-engineering, such as computers or radios. The rifle clutched in your chitinous hands was a deep red colour, and in shape was similar to most of the 'assault rifles' of the twentieth and twenty first centuries. However, instead of a barrel, there was a small maw, three small mandibles jutting out of the crimson flesh to meet in front of the maw. When the 'trigger' - in actuality an exposed muscle - was pulled, the mandibles spread apart as a payload of solid bone was launched from the maw. Stroking a certain area on the rifle caused a membrane to cover the trigger muscles, preventing the rifle from firing.

Protruding from the bottom of the rifle's grip was a thin nerve strand, deep purple in colour. This nerve plugged into a port on the palms of your armour, linking the rifle into your HUD. The HUD was a strange thing. Your armour, jacking directly into your optic nerves, and being supplied with information about your weapons, your health, and your squad mates, superimposed a HUD over your vision. When you removed the armour, the HUD disappeared, although it took a couple of minutes for your vision to get back to normal.

Flicking your eyes up to the practice targets in front of you, you line your rifle up with the one that was in your immediate vision. Such was your concentration, that the rest of the world seemed to blur out of focus slightly as you fired into the classic 'bullseye' style target, hitting just off center.

You were currently at a firing range. The firing range of your current base, to be exact. As was the case with most military bases, the walls were a boring white bone, as were the ceilings and floors. Small bio-heaters provided warmth at set intervals, the fleshy lumps radiating heat outwards. Several targets were arrayed at the end of each of a series of long corridors, allowing maximum focus.

Grunting, you roll your shoulders and place your rifle on your back, where a small layer of muscle rapidly grows over it, so as to keep it in place. Reaching up to your head, you grip your helmet and gradually seperate it from the rest of your armour, layers of sinew used to lock it in place easily ripping under force. Feeling a jolt of an impulse as you disconnect the nerves from their plugs in your neck and head, you rub the back side of your helmet, which was composed of several thick slabs of muscle.

"Ah, don't worry, girl," you coo as you pet the helmet, feeling the muscle squirm slightly under your touch. "We'll play again later."

Placing the helmet on your back for safekeeping, you exit the room, making your way towards the barracks. It was pretty late, and a tired soldier was a useless soldier. Better catch up on some sleep, then!
